Award.AwardTitle: "Nonparametric Regression Methods For Nonlinear Time Series Models"
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this project is to develop the methodology for estimation and testing of the nonlinear time series models involving a large number of predictor variables. The key idea is to adapt a number of techniques that are used in the nonparametric regression theory and that can be, after suitable justification, transferred to the time series setting. In addition to the above, the decision-theoretic properties of the resulting estimators are established for the first time. This is achieved by establishing asymptotic equivalence results between the nonparametric regression and various nonlinear time series models.

The models studied in this project are very commonly encountered in different areas of application. Many of these are the areas of federal strategic interest. As an example, one can mention forecasting the levels of future flooding and predicting the volume of production in many areas of industry. Another very important area of application is building the models that explain long-term changes in sea surface temperature and, by doing so, help explain and predict the future changes in the global climate. All of the above models often include a lot of predictor variables and this makes the choice of the model needed very difficult in practice. Based on the methods and tests proposed in this project, efficient model selection procedures can be enacted that can greatly help in choosing the right model. After the right model is chosen, high quality forecasts can be obtained that are not only of interest for researchers in science, but that also benefit society as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Nonparametric Regression Methods For Nonlinear Time Series Models" has been mostly dedicated to adaptation of methods that are well known to researchers working on nonparametric regression to related time series models. Today, high-dimensional data involving a large number of variables are commonly generated in different areas, such as scientific research, government, business etc. These data need to be, first, interpreted, and, then explained in terms of new models. The final stage often consists of using the best possible models for prediction purposes. Such datasets have not been available until recently, and, therefore, the models that can explain them well are in a state of relative infancy. The resulting challenge is particularly severe when such data are extensively correlated over time, representing a high dimensional time series. This situation is commonly encountered in ecology, climatology, empirical finance and a number of other areas of science.  The enormous amount of available information makes it imperative to select the simplest possible and adequate model structure to ensure that the model can be adequately estimated and that its interpretation makes sense. That is why work on highly nonlinear multivariate time series models acquired new sense of urgency in the last decade. 

Also, there are many practical situations where the response to a large number of experimental stimuli is investigated (for example, in developmental psychology); it is generally suspected beforehand that the subjects of experiment will exhibit different reactions to these stimuli but it is not clear just how many different responses can be expected. As an example, children may be given a task that is commonly expected to be performed in a different way by children at different stages of development.  It is often difficult to describe the variety of possible responses in this case, especially when the number of possible stimuli investigated is large and this is where the analysis of the so-called multivariate mixtures becomes useful.

As a result of this project, the PI proposed a number of time series models capable of modeling phenomena such as freshwater floods, volatility of various financial assets etc.  The models have been shown to be reasonably adequate in explaining real data and estimation methods for these models have been designed as well. Also, the PI designed a convenient algorithm that allows estimation of the number of such groups in many practically important cases that is efficient and possesses a number of other attractive properties. Some of the methods described have already been coded and are available for practical use as part of R statistical programming environment. The PI also trained several graduate students who will go on to join the new generation of scientists capable of research on high-dimensional time series.
